text: this is kit Eaton for the New York Times
we all know how dreary business meetings
can get but thanks to apps like meetings
notebooks for work your smartphone or
tablet can bring your meetings right
into the 21st century meetings notebooks
for work which is a four-dollar iOS app
is essentially a smart digital companion
for your meetings that tries to help you
keep organized it's best to think of
this app as a kind of log book somewhere
where before meetings you can plan who
to invite and set out a basic agenda and
where during meetings you can keep
digital notes of what's discussed this
app tries to help you making your notes
by offering quick buttons to insert
bullet points or time stamps there's
also a section for action items so you
can describe actions to be taken after
the meeting as well as assigning due
dates and responsible people to them if
the look and feel of meetings notebooks
for work doesn't appeal to you check out
meeting minutes pro this app which is
available for Android devices is very
similar in purpose while having a
slightly different design and look and
feel it also boasts a few neat extras
such as being able to export your notes
file in a format that's compatible with
microsoft word which means you can edit
it when you back at the office this app
costs four dollars but there is a three
day free trial version lastly if you're
like me you find yourself regularly
scheduling meetings with participants
who are dialing in from different
continents and therefore different time
zones the app time Powell easy meeting
planner across time zones can help with
this task because it's designed to let
you know where you're meeting attendees
cities are in terms of time and thus
makes the business of scheduling
meetings at appropriate times for
different participants a little bit
easier the app is again very simple but
potentially extremely useful and it
costs just two dollars on iOS and that's
it good luck modernizing your meetings
Oh
